subdomain: Standard 5: Advertising and Other Public Statements

questions.stem: Under Standard 5.01 (Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements), a psychologist posts a social media advertisement stating they have a 95% success rate in treating depression. They base this on uncontrolled client self-reports. This statement is most likely:

options.text: Acceptable because it is based on client feedback
A violation because it is a false or deceptive claim not supported by valid evidence
Acceptable if the psychologist genuinely believes the claim
A violation only if a competitor files a formal complaint

questions.explanation: Standard 5.01 prohibits psychologists from making false, deceptive, or fraudulent statements about their work. A claim of 95% success rate based on uncontrolled self-reports is misleading because it implies scientific rigor without a valid evidence base. Subjective client reports without standardized outcome measures, control conditions, or systematic data collection do not support such a specific claim. This standard applies regardless of the psychologist's belief or whether a complaint is filed.

questions.stem: Standard 5.04 (Media Presentations) requires that when psychologists provide advice or commentary through public media, they should:

options.text: Avoid all media appearances to protect the profession
Take precautions to ensure that statements are based on appropriate psychological literature and practice, and are consistent with the Ethics Code
Only discuss topics where there is unanimous professional consensus
Always provide specific diagnoses when asked about public figures

questions.explanation: Standard 5.04 does not prohibit media appearances but requires psychologists to take precautions ensuring their statements are based on appropriate professional literature and practice and consistent with the Ethics Code. They should not provide specific diagnoses of individuals they haven't examined (the 'Goldwater Rule'). They can discuss topics with professional disagreement as long as they represent the state of knowledge accurately. Media appearances are a legitimate form of public education.

questions.stem: Standard 5.05 (Testimonials) addresses the solicitation of testimonials from clients. A psychologist asks current therapy clients to write positive reviews on Google to help build the practice. This action is:

options.text: Acceptable because the reviews are voluntary
A violation because psychologists should not solicit testimonials from current clients who, due to their circumstances, are vulnerable to undue influence
Acceptable only if the psychologist provides a template for the review
Acceptable if the psychologist offers a discount in exchange for the review

questions.explanation: Standard 5.05 prohibits psychologists from soliciting testimonials from current therapy clients or other persons who, because of their particular circumstances, are vulnerable to undue influence. Current clients are in a therapeutic relationship with an inherent power differential—they may feel pressure to comply with the request out of a desire to maintain the therapist's goodwill or avoid perceived negative consequences for their treatment. This applies to all platforms including Google, Yelp, and social media. Offering discounts for reviews would compound the violation by adding financial inducement.

questions.stem: A psychologist is invited to give a workshop on mindfulness-based stress reduction. Under Standard 5.03 (Descriptions of Workshops and Non-Degree-Granting Educational Programs), the psychologist must ensure that:

options.text: The workshop description promises specific outcomes such as complete stress elimination
The description accurately states the target audience, educational objectives, presenters, and fees
The workshop title includes superlative claims to maximize attendance
No description is provided because workshops are exempt from advertising standards

questions.explanation: Standard 5.03 requires that descriptions of workshops and non-degree-granting educational programs be accurate and not misleading. This includes truthfully representing the target audience, educational objectives, presenters and their qualifications, and fees. Promising specific outcomes like complete stress elimination would be a false and deceptive claim. Superlative claims without evidence would violate Standard 5.01. Workshops are not exempt from advertising standards—all public statements by psychologists must be accurate and non-deceptive.

questions.stem: Standard 5.06 (In-Person Solicitation) addresses psychologists who solicit business from potential clients who may be vulnerable. A psychologist who recently published a book on grief therapy visits a bereavement support group and distributes business cards to attendees, encouraging them to schedule therapy appointments. This action:

options.text: Is acceptable because the psychologist is marketing relevant services
Violates Standard 5.06 because in-person solicitation of persons in vulnerable emotional states constitutes undue influence
Is acceptable if the psychologist also provides free resources at the event
Is only a violation if the psychologist charges above the usual rate

questions.explanation: Standard 5.06 prohibits psychologists from engaging in uninvited in-person solicitation of business from actual or potential therapy clients/patients or other persons who because of their particular circumstances are vulnerable to undue influence. Persons attending a bereavement support group are in an emotionally vulnerable state, and direct solicitation in that context exploits their vulnerability. The fact that the psychologist has relevant expertise does not justify the solicitation. Providing free resources does not offset the impropriety of soliciting vulnerable individuals. The standard aims to protect people from being pressured into professional relationships during moments of vulnerability.

questions.stem: Under Standard 5.01, which of the following constitute false or deceptive statements by psychologists? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Claiming a degree from an institution that is not accredited
Listing all actual degrees and certifications on a professional website
Implying false scientific validation for a therapeutic technique
Using client testimonials that exaggerate treatment outcomes
Stating that one is a licensed psychologist when one actually holds a valid license

questions.explanation: Violations of Standard 5.01 include: claiming unaccredited degrees (A) misrepresents qualifications; implying false scientific validation (C) is deceptive about evidence base; exaggerated testimonials (D) are misleading about expected outcomes. Accurately listing real credentials (B) and truthfully stating one's license status (E) are not deceptive and are consistent with the standard.

questions.stem: Under Standard 5.02 (Statements by Others), a psychologist is responsible for which aspects of how others represent them? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Taking reasonable steps to correct false statements made by others about the psychologist's credentials
Ensuring that paid advertisements are accurate and not misleading
Taking responsibility for every comment made about them on the internet
Preventing others whom they compensate from making deceptive statements
Reviewing and correcting any paid promotions created by others on their behalf

questions.explanation: Standard 5.02 requires psychologists to take reasonable steps to prevent others (especially those they compensate) from making deceptive statements about them. This includes correcting known false statements (A), ensuring paid advertisements are accurate (B), preventing paid agents from being deceptive (D), and reviewing paid promotions (E). The standard does not require monitoring all internet comments (C), as this would be impractical, but does require action when the psychologist becomes aware of inaccurate paid representations.

questions.stem: Which of the following public statements by psychologists would be consistent with Standard 5? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: A psychologist on a podcast states: 'Research suggests that CBT is effective for many anxiety disorders, though individual outcomes vary'
A psychologist in a TV interview diagnoses a celebrity with narcissistic personality disorder based on their public behavior
A psychologist's website states: 'I am board certified by the American Board of Professional Psychology in Clinical Psychology'—when this is true
A psychologist posts on social media: 'I can cure your PTSD in one session using my proprietary technique'
A psychologist writes a blog post reviewing the research evidence on a controversial therapy technique, noting areas of agreement and disagreement in the field

questions.explanation: Consistent with Standard 5: (A) accurately represents research with appropriate caveats about individual variation; (C) truthfully states a verified credential; (E) provides balanced, evidence-based information. Violations: (B) diagnosing a public figure without examination violates the Goldwater Rule and Standard 5.04 (media statements must be consistent with the Ethics Code); (D) claiming to 'cure' PTSD in one session with a proprietary technique is a false/deceptive claim violating Standard 5.01.

questions.stem: Standard 5.01 identifies several specific types of false or deceptive statements. Which of the following are explicitly referenced as potential violations? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: False statements about the psychologist's training, experience, or competence
False statements about the psychologist's degree or academic credentials
False statements about the scientific or clinical basis for services
Truthful statements about the psychologist's published research findings
False or deceptive statements concerning the psychologist's fees

questions.explanation: Standard 5.01 specifically identifies false statements about: training, experience, or competence (A); academic degrees (B); the scientific or clinical basis for services (C); and fees (E). These encompass the most common areas where psychologists might be tempted to misrepresent themselves. Truthful statements about published research (D) are not a violation—the standard targets false and deceptive statements, not accurate ones. The standard also covers false statements about professional affiliations, publications, and institutional or association connections.

questions.stem: A psychologist maintains an active social media presence to promote their practice. Which of the following social media practices are consistent with Standard 5? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Posting psychoeducational content about common mental health conditions with appropriate caveats
Reposting a client's positive testimonial that the client voluntarily posted, without the client's additional consent
Sharing credentials and specialization areas accurately in the profile biography
Responding to a follower's question with general information while noting it does not constitute a therapeutic relationship
Posting before-and-after success stories using actual client cases without disguising identifying information

questions.explanation: Consistent with Standard 5: Psychoeducational content with caveats (A) is appropriate public education; accurate credential listing (C) is truthful representation; general information with disclaimers (D) avoids creating implied therapeutic relationships. Violations: Reposting a client's testimonial without additional consent (B) raises concerns under Standards 5.05 (testimonials) and 4.01 (confidentiality); using actual client cases without disguise (E) violates Standard 4.07 (confidential information in public statements) and could violate Standard 5.01 (deceptive if outcomes are not representative).

questions.stem: Match each scenario to the most applicable Standard 5 provision:

rows.text: A psychologist's website claims they are 'the best therapist in the state'
A psychologist allows a marketing firm to create an advertisement implying they can cure autism
A psychologist asks current therapy clients to write Yelp reviews
A psychologist on television makes clinical pronouncements about a celebrity's mental health without examination

columns.text: Standard 5.01: Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements

questions.explanation: Claiming to be 'the best' is a false/unverifiable claim under Standard 5.01. Allowing a marketing firm to make deceptive claims falls under Standard 5.02 (responsibility for statements by others). Soliciting reviews from current clients violates Standard 5.05 (testimonials from vulnerable persons). Making clinical pronouncements about celebrities on television violates Standard 5.04 (media presentations must be based on appropriate literature and practice, and diagnosing without examination is improper).

questions.stem: Match each type of public communication to its primary Standard 5 risk:

rows.text: Paid Google advertisement for therapy services
Guest appearance on a health-focused podcast

columns.text: Risk of creating an implied therapeutic relationship with readers/listeners
Risk of credential or service misrepresentation in a paid format
Risk of making unfounded public statements about specific conditions or public figures
Risk of inflating credentials or soliciting testimonials through the platform

questions.explanation: Personal blogs about psychological topics carry the risk that readers may interpret general advice as personalized clinical guidance, creating an implied therapeutic relationship (5.04 concerns). Paid Google ads are most susceptible to credential or service misrepresentation because the format encourages attention-grabbing claims (5.01). Podcast appearances create opportunities to make unfounded public statements about conditions or public figures (5.04). Psychology Today profiles, which include review features and credential listings, carry risks of inflating credentials and soliciting client testimonials (5.01/5.05).

questions.stem: For each type of public statement, select ALL potential ethical concerns under Standard 5:

rows.text: Television interview about mental health topics
Social media posts about psychological topics

columns.text: Risk of false or deceptive claims about credentials
Risk of providing unauthorized diagnosis of public figures
Risk of blurring professional and personal boundaries
Risk of implying therapeutic relationship with followers

questions.explanation: Psychology Today profiles: Risk of inflated credentials (col1) and soliciting testimonials from clients (col5). Television interviews: Risk of credential misrepresentation (col1) and being asked to diagnose public figures (col2, violating the Goldwater Rule). Social media: Risk of credential misrepresentation (col1), blurring professional-personal boundaries (col3), and creating implicit therapeutic relationships with followers who seek advice (col4).

questions.stem: For each Standard 5 provision, select ALL types of conduct that would constitute a violation:

rows.text: Standard 5.01: Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements

columns.text: Allowing a website designer to list nonexistent board certifications on the psychologist's site
Claiming to be an expert in neuropsychology without specialized training
Visiting hospital patients to distribute therapy practice brochures
A practice manager posting fabricated client success stories without the psychologist's knowledge
Approaching accident victims at the scene to offer crisis counseling for a fee

questions.explanation: Standard 5.01 violations: Claiming neuropsychology expertise without training (col2) is a false statement about competence. Standard 5.02 violations: Allowing a designer to list false certifications (col1) and fabricated success stories by a practice manager (col4) are statements by others that the psychologist is responsible for. Standard 5.06 violations: Visiting hospital patients to distribute brochures (col3) and approaching accident victims (col5) constitute in-person solicitation of vulnerable persons.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 5 (Advertising and Other Public Statements):

Standard 5.01 requires that psychologists do not make [BLANK1] statements about their work including their qualifications, services, or research findings. This applies to [BLANK2] as well as traditional advertising. Standard 5.02 holds psychologists responsible for [BLANK3] made by others on their behalf, requiring them to take reasonable steps to ensure accuracy. When providing public advice through media (Standard 5.04), psychologists must ensure their statements are based on [BLANK4]. Standard 5.05 specifically addresses [BLANK5], requiring that psychologists not solicit them from current clients who are vulnerable to undue influence.
questions.explanation: Standard 5 addresses public statements and advertising: 5.01 prohibits false, deceptive, or fraudulent statements across all platforms including social media. 5.02 extends responsibility to statements made by others on the psychologist's behalf. 5.04 requires media statements to be based on appropriate professional literature. 5.05 addresses testimonials, prohibiting solicitation from current clients who may be vulnerable to undue influence.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about the Goldwater Rule and Standard 5.04:

The Goldwater Rule, formalized in [BLANK1] professional ethics, prohibits clinicians from offering professional opinions about individuals they have not personally [BLANK2]. Standard 5.04 requires that public media statements be based on [BLANK3] rather than speculation. When a psychologist is asked to comment on a public figure's mental health during a television interview, the most ethical response is to discuss [BLANK4] rather than offering a specific diagnosis. This principle protects both the [BLANK5] of the individual and the integrity of the profession.

options: general psychological principles and observable behavior patterns without diagnosing
BLANK4.correct: general psychological principles and observable behavior patterns without diagnosing

questions.explanation: The Goldwater Rule, originating from a 1964 political controversy and formalized in both APA (psychiatric) and APA (psychological) ethics, prohibits diagnosing public figures without a personal examination. Standard 5.04 requires that media statements be based on appropriate literature, not speculation. Psychologists can ethically discuss general psychological principles in media contexts without offering diagnoses of specific individuals. This protects individuals' rights and dignity while maintaining the profession's credibility.

questions.stem: A psychologist discovers that their practice manager has been posting client testimonials on the practice's website without obtaining proper consent from the clients. Some testimonials include details that could identify the clients to others who know them.
questions.centerQuestion: Which ethical standard is most directly violated in this situation?

options.text: Client confidentiality has been breached through identifiable testimonials
The psychologist failed to supervise statements made by others on their behalf
Clients may have felt pressured to provide testimonials
The psychologist personally wrote the testimonials
Immediately remove the testimonials from the website
Implement oversight procedures for all public-facing content
Ignore the issue since the practice manager is responsible, not the psychologist
Contact affected clients to inform them and apologize for the confidentiality breach

centerOptions.text: Standard 5.01: Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements

questions.explanation: Standard 5.05 (Testimonials) is most directly violated because it addresses the solicitation and use of client testimonials. This standard intersects with 5.02 (responsibility for statements by others) and 4.01 (confidentiality). Contributing issues include confidentiality breaches, failure to supervise public statements, and potential coercion of vulnerable clients. The psychologist must immediately remove the testimonials, implement oversight, and inform affected clients.

questions.stem: A psychologist has recently completed a weekend certification in EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing). Their website now prominently states: 'Dr. Jones is an EMDR expert and leading authority on trauma treatment. Our clinic achieves remarkable results in just 1-2 sessions.' The psychologist has treated only three clients using EMDR.
questions.centerQuestion: Which ethical standard is most directly violated by the website claims?

options.text: Claiming 'expert' status after a single weekend training misrepresents competence level
'Leading authority' is an unverifiable superlative claim
'Remarkable results in 1-2 sessions' implies guaranteed rapid outcomes without supporting evidence
The psychologist completed a legitimate certification program
Revise the website to accurately state 'trained in EMDR' rather than 'expert'
Remove unverifiable claims and outcome promises
Add qualifiers to outcome claims based on published research rather than personal experience
Keep the website as is because it attracts more clients

centerOptions.text: Standard 5.01: Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements

questions.explanation: Standard 5.01 is most directly violated because the website contains multiple false or deceptive claims: 'expert' status after minimal training misrepresents competence; 'leading authority' is an unverifiable superlative; and promising 'remarkable results in 1-2 sessions' is unsupported and misleading. While Standard 2.01 (competence) is also relevant, the advertising claims are the most direct violation. Corrective actions include accurately representing training level, removing superlatives and outcome guarantees, and referencing published research rather than limited personal experience.

questions.stem: A psychologist is reviewing their practice's advertising materials for compliance with Standard 5. Highlight the THREE statements that would constitute ethical violations:
questions.passage: (A) 'Dr. Smith is a licensed psychologist with a PhD from an APA-accredited program.' (B) 'Our practice guarantees that therapy will cure your anxiety within 6 sessions.' (C) 'We specialize in evidence-based treatments including CBT and DBT.' (D) 'Dr. Smith was voted Best Therapist by City Magazine readers.' (E) 'Our revolutionary technique, developed by Dr. Smith, has been scientifically proven to eliminate PTSD permanently.' (F) 'We accept most major insurance plans and offer a sliding scale.' (G) 'Read what our clients say about their experience!' followed by testimonials solicited from current clients in treatment.
questions.explanation: Violations: (B) Guaranteeing cure within a specific number of sessions is a false and deceptive claim that no therapist can substantiate. (E) Claiming a technique has been 'scientifically proven to eliminate PTSD permanently' is a false claim unless supported by rigorous research, and 'permanently' is likely indefensible. (G) Soliciting testimonials from current clients violates Standard 5.05 because current clients are vulnerable to undue influence. Statements A, C, D, and F are factual, accurate, and not deceptive.

questions.stem: A psychology ethics instructor is evaluating student knowledge of Standard 5. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about advertising and public statements:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 5.01 applies only to print advertisements and does not cover social media, websites, or verbal claims. (B) Psychologists are responsible for ensuring that statements made by employees or agents on their behalf are accurate and not deceptive. (C) A psychologist may accurately state their actual degrees, licenses, and board certifications in any advertising format. (D) Standard 5.04 permits psychologists to make media statements as long as they are based on appropriate psychological literature and consistent with the Ethics Code. (E) Psychologists may freely solicit testimonials from any past or present client without restriction. (F) Descriptions of workshops must accurately represent the educational objectives, presenters, and fees. (G) A psychologist who discovers inaccurate claims on their website made by a web designer has no obligation to correct them. (H) Standard 5.06 prohibits uninvited in-person solicitation of business from persons who are vulnerable to undue influence.
questions.explanation: (B) Standard 5.02 holds psychologists responsible for statements by others they compensate or employ. (D) Standard 5.04 permits media statements when grounded in appropriate literature. (F) Standard 5.03 requires accurate workshop descriptions. (H) Standard 5.06 prohibits in-person solicitation of vulnerable persons. Incorrect: (A) Standard 5.01 applies to ALL public statements, not just print; (C) is actually accurate but only 4 answers are needed and these are the most directly referenced; (E) Soliciting from current clients is prohibited (5.05); (G) Psychologists must take reasonable steps to correct inaccurate representations (5.02).

questions.stem: Arrange the elements of creating a compliant advertising presence for a psychology practice, from first to last:

options.text: Review all content for accuracy and compliance with Standard 5.01
Identify the factual information to include (credentials, specializations, location, insurance)
Establish a system for monitoring and updating public-facing content
Train staff on Standard 5.02 requirements for statements made on the psychologist's behalf
Ensure any claims about effectiveness are supported by appropriate evidence

questions.explanation: Building compliant advertising: Start by identifying factual, verifiable information about the practice. Ensure any effectiveness claims have proper evidentiary support. Review all content for accuracy and Ethics Code compliance (Standard 5.01). Train staff to understand their role in representing the psychologist accurately (Standard 5.02). Finally, establish ongoing monitoring to ensure continued compliance as content is updated or added.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps a psychologist should take when they discover that a former employee has been making false claims about the practice on social media, from first to last:

options.text: Consult with an attorney about legal options for removing the false statements
Identify all platforms and specific false claims being made
Implement preventive measures to reduce future unauthorized statements (e.g., clear social media policies, access controls)
Document the false statements and attempts to correct them for ethics and legal records
Take reasonable steps to have the false statements corrected or removed through platform reporting mechanisms

questions.explanation: The correct sequence: First, identify the scope of the problem—what false claims exist and on which platforms. Document everything for potential legal or ethics proceedings. Take immediate reasonable steps to correct or remove the false statements through platform mechanisms. If self-help measures are insufficient, consult legal counsel about additional remedies. Finally, implement preventive measures such as clear social media policies, limited access to practice accounts, and regular monitoring. Standard 5.02 requires reasonable steps, not necessarily complete elimination of all false statements.

questions.stem: A state licensing board tracks advertising complaints against psychologists over a 10-year period:

questions.question: What does the trend in social media advertising complaints suggest for the profession?

options.text: Social media should be banned for psychologists
Psychologists need more training on ethical social media use and Standard 5 compliance
Social media complaints are unimportant because the platform is informal
The increase reflects better enforcement rather than more violations

questions.question: Why have traditional advertising complaints decreased over the same period?

options.text: Traditional advertising is now more ethical than social media
Fewer psychologists use traditional advertising as digital platforms dominate
The Ethics Code no longer applies to print advertising
Print and radio outlets have stricter internal review processes

questions.explanation: The dramatic increase in social media advertising complaints reflects the profession's rapid shift to digital marketing without corresponding training in ethical digital presence. Psychologists need education on how Standard 5 applies to social media platforms. The decline in traditional advertising complaints reflects the overall shift away from print and radio advertising rather than improvements in traditional advertising ethics. Website complaints remained relatively stable, suggesting established practices for website compliance.

questions.stem: A professional organization surveys psychologists about their advertising practices and compliance awareness across 5 years:

datasets.name: Psychologists using social media for practice promotion (%)
Psychologists who reviewed Standard 5 before creating ads (%)
Psychologists reporting uncertainty about digital advertising ethics (%)

questions.question: What does the divergence between social media adoption and Standard 5 review suggest?

options.text: Standard 5 is no longer relevant to modern practice
There is a growing gap between digital advertising practices and ethical compliance awareness, creating increased risk of violations
Psychologists who use social media are inherently more ethical
The Ethics Code should be simplified to encourage more reading

questions.question: What intervention would most effectively address the rising uncertainty about digital advertising ethics?

options.text: Banning psychologists from social media advertising
Mandatory continuing education on applying Standard 5 to digital platforms, including practical case examples
Eliminating Standard 5 requirements for digital content
Having licensing boards review all psychologist social media accounts

questions.explanation: The data reveals a concerning trend: social media adoption for practice promotion has tripled (25% to 78%) while the percentage of psychologists reviewing Standard 5 before creating ads has declined (45% to 28%), and uncertainty about digital advertising ethics has doubled (30% to 60%). This growing gap between practice and knowledge creates elevated risk for Standard 5 violations. The most effective intervention is mandatory continuing education that bridges this gap by providing practical, platform-specific guidance for applying Standard 5 principles to digital contexts.

questions.stem: Categorize each advertising statement as either compliant or non-compliant with Standard 5:

items.text: 'Licensed clinical psychologist specializing in anxiety disorders'
'Evidence-based treatment approaches including CBT and exposure therapy'
'My unique method cures ADHD without medication, based on my proprietary research'
'PhD in Clinical Psychology from [University Name], APA-accredited program'
'Board certified in clinical psychology by the American Board of Professional Psychology'
'As seen on [TV show name]' when the appearance actually occurred

questions.explanation: Compliant statements are factual and verifiable: actual license status and specialization (item1), named evidence-based approaches (item3), verified degree (item5), actual board certification (item6), and verified media appearance (item8). Non-compliant: guaranteeing results (item2) is deceptive, claiming to cure ADHD with unvalidated methods (item4) is false, and 'world's leading expert' (item7) is an unverifiable superlative claim.

questions.stem: Categorize each situation according to the most relevant Standard 5 provision:

categories.label: Standard 5.01: Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements
Standard 5.02/5.05: Statements by Others and Testimonials

items.text: A psychologist claims a PhD when they hold a PsyD
A practice manager posts fabricated reviews on Google without the psychologist's knowledge
A psychologist diagnoses a celebrity during a radio interview without having examined them
A psychologist advertises 'guaranteed cure for OCD in 3 sessions'
A psychologist hands out business cards at a grief support group meeting
A psychologist encourages current therapy clients to post positive reviews online

questions.explanation: Standard 5.01: Claiming a PhD when holding a PsyD (item1) is a false credential statement; guaranteeing a cure (item4) is a deceptive outcome claim. Standard 5.02/5.05: Fabricated reviews by a practice manager (item2) are unauthorized statements by others; encouraging current clients to post reviews (item6) is improper testimonial solicitation. Standard 5.04/5.06: Diagnosing a celebrity on-air (item3) violates media presentation standards; soliciting at a grief group (item5) is in-person solicitation of vulnerable persons.
